Meeting
In reaction to the issue of
restaurant discrimination, Dr.
Chester Wickwire, YMCA executive secretary, called a second
informal meeting this Tuesday
of various campus leaders and
others interested in this problem.
Present at this meeting were:
Dr. W. Kelso Morrill, Dean of
Students; Dr. G. Wilson Shaffer,
Dean of the Homewood Schools;
Bill DeVoe, president of the
Student Council; Al Powdermaker, president of the IFC;
Stanley Handmaker and Niels
Sundermeyer, editors of the
News-Letter; Peter Kivic, contributing editor of the News-Letter; and John Katz, Jack Alpert,
Oz Garcia, Bob Reinhold, Carl
Rinzler and Don Perry, leaders
of the campus anti-discrimination movement; Erhard Joeres,
Marshall Goldman, and Bob
Dickens of the YMCA; Wally Orlinsky of the Young Democrats.
and Dr. Wickwire.
Against Discrimination
The students, led by John
Katz and Don Perry, stated that
their policy is "To carry the concept of no racial discrimination
off-campus . . . to those places
patronized by Hopkins students,"
and pointed out that the Negro
students of Hopkins cannot leave
campus without being assaulted
by the action of neighbors. "They

JHU Celebrates 84th Anniversary
With Commemoration Awards Under In
Annual commemoration festivities Monday, February 22, to
celebrate the 84th anniversary
of the founding of the Johns
Hopkins University, were climaxed by the presentation of
the honorary degree of Doctor
of Laws upon Dr. Stanhope
Bayne-Jones, noted bacteriologist and medical educator.
Following the Procession of
Johns Hopkins University President Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower,

University Drops
35 Undergrads
After First Term
A survey of withdrawal cases
and flunkout casualties for the
first semester shows that 35 undergraduates—double last year's
total of 17—were dropped by the
University for academic failure.
This increase is most evident
In the school of Arts and
Sciences, which dropped 18 students this February as compared
to 8 last year. Nine engineering
students were sent on their way
this year, as against 6 one year
ago, and the Business and Industrial Management School dispatched eight undergraduates,
five more than last year's total.
Total Of 88
Thirty-one students withdrew
voluntarily at the close of last
semester, and 22 left during the
course of the term, to bring the
total of undergraduate withdrawals as of February, 1960, to
88. Last year's first-semester
total of departures was only 70
students;----17 fell short of the
mark academically, 39 withdrew
voluntarily at the end of the
term and 14 disembarked during
the semester.
Reasons given, either by the
administration or by the student,
for withdrawal, break down as
follows:
Thirty-eight students left this
year and 36 last year for scholastic reasons, but only three withdrew voluntarily this February,
as against 19 one year ago.
Therefore, although scholasticwithdrawal totals are almost
identical for both years, the
great majority (92%) this FeFebruary did not depart of their
own accord.

meeting that the fraternities

University Band
Presents Concert
In Shriver Hall
The Johns Hopkins UniversitY
Band, conducted by Conrad
Gebelein, will present its annual
Spring Concert Saturday, March
5, at 8:30 p.m. in Shriver Hall.
Admission for the traditional al'
fair is free.
This year's concert will feature
Miss Doris Asbell, a local Lyric
Soprano, who will sing selections
from My Fair Lady and La
Bokeme, announced band presi"
dent, Tom Marcellas.
Other selections for the Program include A. Thomas' "RaYmond Overture," Humperdinck's
"The Children's Prayer," V•
Youman's "Fantasy," Gustav
Hoist's "First Suite in E Flat for
Military Band," selections froro
F. Loewe's "Gigi," Strauss' "Err"

mark "Gebby's" thirty-sixth year
as part of the Hopkins Cornmunity. "Gebby" helped to or"

banjo club during this period.

8:41 PM The laments in Kay Starr's new release aren't dangerously
lugubrious and, actually, should stimulate casual entrances onto the
dance floor. That's due to Kay's ardent, ringing style and the lush
string background which is under only mild sedation behind her.
Anybody downcast after hearing Into Each Life Some Rain Must
Fall, I Should Care, Please Don't Talk About Me When I'm Gone
or the others isn't in a mood to enjoy or contribute much to things
anyway, and might appreciate a thoughtful suggestion that there's
probably still time to make it to the library before it closes.

9:22 PM If the party's billed as'a "Dance," this is as good a time

as any to find out how seriously it is meant. Put on the new Kenton
album; it's in the lit-up Latin tradition of Peanut Vendor. Some
numbers, like Adios, are fairly relaxed, but most—e.g., a sizzling
new Artistry in Rhythm--test dancing prowess. It should separate
the men from the boys. (If it separates the men from the girls, try

The End Of An Era
Last Tuesday night the News-Letter walked out of
Bonnie's Restaurant in protest against their refusal to
serve the group because it included one Negro, thus ending one of this newspaper's favorite traditions.
For over a decade Bonnie's, affectionately known in
this circle as "the Pizza Queen," has been the location of
the regular Tuesday night assemblage of our editors-inchief, page editors and staff following completion of each
week's issue of the News-Letter.
In leaving the restaurant this week the staff of this
paper has ended an era. We may have lost an old friend,
but we cannot conscientiously patronize an establishment
which may exclude one of our number, until the policy
of this establishment changes.
Bonnie's has provided the News-Letter with good food
and the atmosphere of animated conversation which for
many years have eased the rather hectic business of putting together our newspaper. We shall miss our customary Tuesday night "haunt," and we hope that this breach
in our attachment to Bonnie's will not be permanent.

Today, as everyone knows, is the forty-sixth anniversary of the
-founding of Gransmire College for Women, which, as everyone
knows, was the first Progressive Education college in the
United States.
Well do I recollect the tizzy in the academic world when
Gransmire opened its portals! What a buzz there was, what a
brouhaha in faculty common rooms, what a rattling of teacups,
When. Dr. Agnes Thudd Sigafoos, first president of Gransmire,
lifted her learned old head and announced defiantly, "We will
teach the student, not the course. There will be no marks, no
exams, no requirements. This, by George, is Progressive
Education!"
Well sir, forward-looking maidens all over the country cast
off their fetters and came rushing to New Hampshire to enroll
at Gransmire. Here they found freedom. They broadened their
vistas. They lengthened their horizons. They unstopped their
bottled personalities. They roamed the campus in togas, leading ocelots on leashes.
And, of course, they smoked Marlboro cigarettes. (I say,"Of
course." Why do I say,"Of curse"? I say;"Of course" because
it is a matter of course that anyone in search of freedom should
-naturally turn to Marlboro,for Marlboro is the smoke that sets
the spirit soaring, that unyokes the captive soul, that fills the
air with the murmur of wings. If you think flavor went out
When filters came in—try Marlboro. They are sold in soft pack
or flip-top box wherever freedom rings.)
But all was not Marlboro and ocelots for the girls of Grans/tire. There was work and study too—not in the ordinary sense,
to be sure, for there were no formal classes. Instead there was
a broad approach to enlarging each girl's potentials, both mental
and physical.
Take, for example, the course called B.M.S. (Basic Motor
Skills). B.M.S. was divided into L.D. (Lying Down), S.U.
(Standing Up) and W.(Walking). Once the student had mastered L.D. and S.U.,she was taught to W.—but not just to W.
any old way! No, sir! She was taught to W. with poise,
dignity, bearing! To inculcate a sense of balance in the girl,
she began her exercises by walking with a suitcase in each hand.
(One girl, Mary Ellen Dorgenicht, got so good at it that today
She is bell captain at the Deshler-Hilton Hotel in Columbus,
Ohio.) '

When the girls had walking under their belts, they were
allowed to dance. Again no formality was imposed. They were
simply told to fling themselves about in any way their impulses
dictated, and, believe you me,it was quite an impressive sight
to see them go bounding into the woods with their togas flying.
(Several later joined the U.S. Forestry Service.)
There was also a lot of finger painting and sculpture with
Coat hangers and like that, and soon the fresh wind of Progre,saivism came whistling out of Gransmire to blow the ancient dust
Of pedantry off curricula everywhere, and today, thanks to the
Pioneers at Gransmire, we are all free.
If you are ever in New Hampshire, be sure to visit the Grans1900 Mai kilaulinra

John T. Bell majored in History and Economics at the University of Georgia. On
graduating in June, 1957, he joined the
Southern Bell Telephone Company.
Today—less than three years later—he
is a Public Office Manager for the company at Orlando, Florida. His office serves
50,000 telephone accounts and handles
more than a million dollars' worth of
'revenue every month.
John says: "I chose a telephone career
over a number of others because I was
impressed by the company's Management
Training Program and the opportunities
offered for rapid advancement. It was the
best decision I ever made."

assignments familiarized him with overall company operations. Then he transferred to Orlando, where he trained as a

Meeting
In reaction to the issue of
restaurant discrimination, Dr.
Chester Wickwire, YMCA executive secretary, called a second
informal meeting this Tuesday
of various campus leaders and
others interested in this problem.
Present at this meeting were:
Dr. W. Kelso Morrill, Dean of
Students; Dr. G. Wilson Shaffer,
Dean of the Homewood Schools;
Bill DeVoe, president of the
Student Council; Al Powdermaker, president of the IFC;
Stanley Handmaker and Niels
Sundermeyer, editors of the
News-Letter; Peter Kivic, contributing editor of the News-Letter; and John Katz, Jack Alpert,
Oz Garcia, Bob Reinhold, Carl
Rinzler and Don Perry, leaders
of the campus anti-discrimination movement; Erhard Joeres,
Marshall Goldman, and Bob
Dickens of the YMCA; Wally Orlinsky of the Young Democrats.
and Dr. Wickwire.
Against Discrimination
The students, led by John
Katz and Don Perry, stated that
their policy is "To carry the concept of no racial discrimination
off-campus . . . to those places
patronized by Hopkins students,"
and pointed out that the Negro
students of Hopkins cannot leave
campus without being assaulted
by the action of neighbors. "They

Annual commemoration festivities Monday, February 22, to
celebrate the 84th anniversary
of the founding of the Johns
Hopkins University, were climaxed by the presentation of
the honorary degree of Doctor
of Laws upon Dr. Stanhope
Bayne-Jones, noted bacteriologist and medical educator.
Following the Procession of
Johns Hopkins University President Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower,

University Drops
35 Undergrads
After First Term
A survey of withdrawal cases
and flunkout casualties for the
first semester shows that 35 undergraduates—double last year's
total of 17—were dropped by the
University for academic failure.
This increase is most evident
In the school of Arts and
Sciences, which dropped 18 students this February as compared
to 8 last year. Nine engineering
students were sent on their way
this year, as against 6 one year
ago, and the Business and Industrial Management School dispatched eight undergraduates,
five more than last year's total.
Total Of 88
Thirty-one students withdrew
voluntarily at the close of last
semester, and 22 left during the
course of the term, to bring the
total of undergraduate withdrawals as of February, 1960, to
88. Last year's first-semester
total of departures was only 70
students;----17 fell short of the
mark academically, 39 withdrew
voluntarily at the end of the
term and 14 disembarked during
the semester.
Reasons given, either by the
administration or by the student,
for withdrawal, break down as
follows:
Thirty-eight students left this
year and 36 last year for scholastic reasons, but only three withdrew voluntarily this February,
as against 19 one year ago.
Therefore, although scholasticwithdrawal totals are almost
identical for both years, the
great majority (92%) this FeFebruary did not depart of their
own accord.

8:41 PM The laments in Kay Starr's new release aren't dangerously
lugubrious and, actually, should stimulate casual entrances onto the
dance floor. That's due to Kay's ardent, ringing style and the lush
string background which is under only mild sedation behind her.
Anybody downcast after hearing Into Each Life Some Rain Must
Fall, I Should Care, Please Don't Talk About Me When I'm Gone
or the others isn't in a mood to enjoy or contribute much to things
anyway, and might appreciate a thoughtful suggestion that there's
probably still time to make it to the library before it closes.

9:22 PM If the party's billed as'a "Dance," this is as good a time

as any to find out how seriously it is meant. Put on the new Kenton
album; it's in the lit-up Latin tradition of Peanut Vendor. Some
numbers, like Adios, are fairly relaxed, but most—e.g., a sizzling
new Artistry in Rhythm--test dancing prowess. It should separate
the men from the boys. (If it separates the men from the girls, try
the music in Capitol's "Arthur Murray" series. Sets of sambas, foxtrots, etc. with top bands'and good for pleasant, low-pressure
dancing. Little pictures show where to put your feet.)

10:07 PM While the blood is up, put on Ray Anthony's latest,
"Like Wild!" The title means much the same as "It's the cat's
pajamas" but says it faster, in keeping with today's modern, high.
speed living. Both expressions become clear when the record is
played, for it's a fine, swinging, powerhouse of brass effects, some
delectable, some almost alarming. Anthony plays new stuff and
ones like Peter Gunn Theme, Room 43, 707 and Walkin' to Mother's
that he's already made a lot of money on as singles. An intermission
will be needed. Who won the basketball game?

The End Of An Era
Last Tuesday night the News-Letter walked out of
Bonnie's Restaurant in protest against their refusal to
serve the group because it included one Negro, thus ending one of this newspaper's favorite traditions.
For over a decade Bonnie's, affectionately known in
this circle as "the Pizza Queen," has been the location of
the regular Tuesday night assemblage of our editors-inchief, page editors and staff following completion of each
week's issue of the News-Letter.
In leaving the restaurant this week the staff of this
paper has ended an era. We may have lost an old friend,
but we cannot conscientiously patronize an establishment
which may exclude one of our number, until the policy
of this establishment changes.
Bonnie's has provided the News-Letter with good food
and the atmosphere of animated conversation which for
many years have eased the rather hectic business of putting together our newspaper. We shall miss our customary Tuesday night "haunt," and we hope that this breach
in our attachment to Bonnie's will not be permanent.

Today, as everyone knows, is the forty-sixth anniversary of the
-founding of Gransmire College for Women, which, as everyone
knows, was the first Progressive Education college in the
United States.
Well do I recollect the tizzy in the academic world when
Gransmire opened its portals! What a buzz there was, what a
brouhaha in faculty common rooms, what a rattling of teacups,
When. Dr. Agnes Thudd Sigafoos, first president of Gransmire,
lifted her learned old head and announced defiantly, "We will
teach the student, not the course. There will be no marks, no
exams, no requirements. This, by George, is Progressive
Education!"
Well sir, forward-looking maidens all over the country cast
off their fetters and came rushing to New Hampshire to enroll
at Gransmire. Here they found freedom. They broadened their
vistas. They lengthened their horizons. They unstopped their
bottled personalities. They roamed the campus in togas, leading ocelots on leashes.
And, of course, they smoked Marlboro cigarettes. (I say,"Of
course." Why do I say,"Of curse"? I say;"Of course" because
it is a matter of course that anyone in search of freedom should
-naturally turn to Marlboro,for Marlboro is the smoke that sets
the spirit soaring, that unyokes the captive soul, that fills the
air with the murmur of wings. If you think flavor went out
When filters came in—try Marlboro. They are sold in soft pack
or flip-top box wherever freedom rings.)
But all was not Marlboro and ocelots for the girls of Grans/tire. There was work and study too—not in the ordinary sense,
to be sure, for there were no formal classes. Instead there was
a broad approach to enlarging each girl's potentials, both mental
and physical.
Take, for example, the course called B.M.S. (Basic Motor
Skills). B.M.S. was divided into L.D. (Lying Down), S.U.
(Standing Up) and W.(Walking). Once the student had mastered L.D. and S.U.,she was taught to W.—but not just to W.
any old way! No, sir! She was taught to W. with poise,
dignity, bearing! To inculcate a sense of balance in the girl,
she began her exercises by walking with a suitcase in each hand.
(One girl, Mary Ellen Dorgenicht, got so good at it that today
She is bell captain at the Deshler-Hilton Hotel in Columbus,
Ohio.) '

When the girls had walking under their belts, they were
allowed to dance. Again no formality was imposed. They were
simply told to fling themselves about in any way their impulses
dictated, and, believe you me,it was quite an impressive sight
to see them go bounding into the woods with their togas flying.
(Several later joined the U.S. Forestry Service.)
There was also a lot of finger painting and sculpture with
Coat hangers and like that, and soon the fresh wind of Progre,saivism came whistling out of Gransmire to blow the ancient dust
Of pedantry off curricula everywhere, and today, thanks to the
Pioneers at Gransmire, we are all free.
If you are ever in New Hampshire, be sure to visit the Grans1900 Mai kilaulinra
